articles.title: BE-Albania reviews progress with the Growth Plan
articles.summary: The Reform Agenda of Albania is closely linked to the EU membership process, designed to provide early membership benefits, to bring the country closer to the EU Single Market, and to strengthen regional cooperation.
articles.content:
The Reform Agenda of Albania is closely linked to the EU membership process, designed to provide early membership benefits, to bring the country closer to the EU Single Market, and to strengthen regional cooperation.

The European Union and the Government of Albania held the first meeting of the Monitoring Commission of the Instrument for Reform and Growth in Tirana, a key element of the EU’s Growth Plan for the Western Balkans. The focus was on how Albania is implementing the reforms that will bring it closer to the European Union and unlock investment opportunities of up to 922 million euros, providing tangible benefits for citizens even before the country’s membership in the EU.

The meeting was co-chaired by Sigrid Brettel, Head of Unit at the Directorate-General for Enlargement and Neighbourhood Policy of the European Commission, and Eridana Çano, National Coordinator of Albania for the Instrument for Reform and Growth and General Director of the State Agency for Strategic Programming and Aid Coordination.

Representatives from independent institutions, civil society, the academic world, international financial institutions from the private sector, and the diplomatic community also participated.

Albania’s Reform Agenda is closely linked to the EU membership process, designed to provide early membership benefits, bring the country closer to the EU Single Market, and strengthen regional cooperation.

Every key achievement of the reforms unlocks EU financial support under the Instrument for Reform and Growth, which, together with pre-accession IPA funds, will further boost Albania’s integration path.

The Commission reviewed Albania’s progress from July 2024 to June 2025, which is currently being assessed by the European Commission, while a full assessment is expected in October. If all reform steps are met, Albania could expect a new grant payment from the Commission, following the preliminary funding of 64.5 million euros allocated so far.

Brettel from the European Commission praised the work of the Albanian administration at all levels in achieving reform objectives. “Now is the time for Albania to double down on reform implementation. By demonstrating its ability to plan, implement, monitor, and deliver results, Albania is showing that it will have the capacity to handle complex EU financial instruments on its future path,” she said.

Çano emphasized that the Instrument for Reform and Growth is more than just a financial package; it represents a new governance model built on cooperation, transparency, accountability, and dialogue.

<p“This process has been transformative. It mobilized the entire government, engaged parliament, independent institutions, and stakeholders, and put our systems to the test under pressure. It revealed both strengths and areas that need improvement. Above all, it demonstrated that Albania can implement reforms on time, transparently, and in accordance with EU standards,” she said.

Participants reviewed reforms in five key areas of Albania’s national agenda: improving the business climate, developing human capital, advancing energy, digital innovation, and infrastructure, as well as strengthening the justice system and the rule of law. They also discussed how reforms can translate into real and visible improvements for people and businesses.

The government presented the monitoring and auditing systems it has created to ensure that funds are managed effectively and transparently, as well as its plans to strengthen communication with citizens.

Participants reiterated their strong commitment to ensuring that the Reform Agenda is successful, as well as emphasized the need to accelerate reforms and investments to advance Albania’s path towards EU membership.

The EU Growth Plan for the Western Balkans aims to bring Albania and other countries in the region early membership benefits in the EU – such as access to the European Single Market and integration into the regional common market – by advancing key reforms.

Through the Instrument for Reform and Growth, Albania can receive up to 922 million euros in loans and grants, depending on how successfully it implements its Reform Agenda.

These reforms address some of Albania’s biggest challenges: the fight against corruption and organized crime, reducing informality in the economy, strengthening the judiciary, improving education and skills, modernizing infrastructure, and supporting energy and digital transitions.

The EU Growth Plan for Albania is an integral part of the overall EU integration process and ongoing negotiations for EU membership. (September 26)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on Albania's significant progress in implementing reforms linked to EU membership, which will bring broad, tangible benefits such as improved governance, rule of law, economic development, and regional cooperation. These reforms address major societal challenges and unlock substantial EU financial support, positively impacting the general population and advancing human rights and democratic standards.

articles.title: China’s Premier Li calls for solidarity, peace and shared economic prosperity in UN address
articles.summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang on Friday marked the UN’s 80th anniversary with a call for world leaders to defend multilateralism, reject “Cold War” thinking and step up cooperation in the face of global turmoil.
articles.content:
“Solidarity lifts everyone up, while division drags all down,” Mr. Li told the General Assembly, warning that unilateralism and protectionism were undermining the international order built over decades.

Humanity, he said, “has once again come to a crossroads.”

Premier Li recalled the defeat of fascism and the founding of the UN eight decades ago, saying the lessons of history demanded renewed commitment to peace, fairness and justice.

“When might dictates right, the world risks division and regression,” he said, urging that all countries, “big or small, be treated as equals.”

China, Mr. Li stressed, was committed to being a “staunch defender of world peace and security.”

He highlighted Beijing’s contributions to UN peacekeeping – the second-largest budgetary contributor and the largest troop contributor among Security Council permanent members – and its role in promoting political solutions to conflicts including Ukraine and the Israel-Palestine crisis.

On the global economy, the Chinese leader said sluggish growth was being worsened by “tariff hikes and erection of walls and barriers.” He pointed to his country’s steady expansion and role as a driver of global development, contributing about 30 percent of economic growth in recent years, and noted the country had lowered tariffs – while remaining the world’s second-largest importer for 16 consecutive years.

Reject ‘civilizational superiority’

China would continue to pursue “high-quality belt and road cooperation” with over 150 countries, he said, while opening its economy wider to the world.

Mr. Li also urged deeper exchanges between societies and warned against “civilizational superiority or ideology-based circles,” which he said bred confrontation.

Turning to global challenges, Mr. Li called for stronger collective action on climate change and emerging technologies.

He said China had built the world’s largest renewable energy system and was advancing low-carbon development. He also urged swift progress on international rules for artificial intelligence, reiterating Beijing’s call for a “world AI cooperation organization.”

As part of its UN engagement, Premier Li announced that China would present lunar soil samples scooped up by its latest robotic explorer from the far side of the moon – the first ever collected – to the United Nations.

He also said China would partner with the UN to establish a China-UN Global South–South Development Facility, with $10 million in initial funding, and a global centre for sustainable development in Shanghai in cooperation with the UN Development Program (UNDP).

“We should adhere to the principles of people-centered development, technology for good, and equitable benefits,” Mr. Li said.

Concluding his address, Mr. Li reaffirmed China’s support for reforms to make the UN “more efficient and representative.”

articles.title: 'Against Erasure': Gaza's photographers fight to be seen
articles.summary: "Art is my way of turning pain into hope." Those are the words of Gaza-based photographer Belal Khaled, whose images have been seen by millions and published in Time, the Guardian and The Wall Street Journal. His work, along with that of 10 other Gaza-based photographers, is at the heart of a powerful new exhibition at P21 Gallery in London, titled "Against Erasure: Photographs from Gaza." In a war where foreign reporters have been banned from Gaza, these photojournalists risk their lives to document what's happening and ensure their stories are not silenced.
articles.content:
'Against Erasure': Gaza's photographers fight to be seen

Culture

From the show

"Art is my way of turning pain into hope." Those are the words of Gaza-based photographer Belal Khaled, whose images have been seen by millions and published in Time, the Guardian and The Wall Street Journal. His work, along with that of 10 other Gaza-based photographers, is at the heart of a powerful new exhibition at P21 Gallery in London, titled "Against Erasure: Photographs from Gaza." In a war where foreign reporters have been banned from Gaza, these photojournalists risk their lives to document what's happening and ensure their stories are not silenced.

articles.reasoning: The article highlights Gaza-based photographers risking their lives to document and share the realities of war despite foreign reporters being banned. This act of bearing witness through art empowers marginalized voices, preserves truth, and fosters global awareness, which is a meaningful human rights contribution with broad societal impact.
articles.personality_title: Gaza photographers share powerful stories despite dangers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Gaza, a region affected by ongoing conflict, foreign reporters are not allowed to enter and report on events. This makes it hard for the world to see what is happening there.

**What happened** – A group of 11 photographers living in Gaza, including Belal Khaled, have been taking pictures that show life and struggles during the war. Their photos are now featured in an exhibition called "Against Erasure: Photographs from Gaza" at the P21 Gallery in London. These photographers risk their safety to capture and share these important images.

**Impact** – These photos give people around the world a chance to understand the reality of life in Gaza, something that might otherwise be hidden. By sharing their work, the photographers make sure the stories of those affected by the war are not forgotten or ignored.

**What's next step** – The exhibition in London will help spread awareness and may inspire more support or interest in Gaza’s situation. It also encourages other artists and journalists to find ways to share important stories despite challenges.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Gaza’s local photographers are bravely using their art to show the world the truth of life in a war zone when others cannot.

**Impact** – Ces photos permettent aux gens dans le monde de mieux comprendre la réalité de la vie à Gaza, quelque chose qui pourrait autrement rester caché. En partageant leur travail, les photographes veillent à ce que les histoires des personnes touchées par la guerre ne soient pas oubliées ou ignorées.

**Prochaine étape** – L’exposition à Londres aidera à faire connaître la situation et pourrait encourager plus de soutien ou d’intérêt pour Gaza. Elle encourage aussi d’autres artistes et journalistes à trouver des moyens de raconter des histoires importantes malgré les difficultés.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les photographes locaux de Gaza utilisent courageusement leur art pour montrer au monde la vérité de la vie en zone de guerre quand d’autres ne le peuvent pas.

articles.title: EU strengthens Europol in the fight against smuggling gangs
articles.summary: 50 million euros, more personnel and more powers: The EU wants to combat smuggling gangs and plans new obligations for the member states.
articles.content:
50 million euros, more personnel and more powers: The EU wants to combat smuggling gangs and plans new obligations for the member states.

Brussels (dpa) – The EU will equip Europol with more money, personnel, and powers in the fight against smuggling gangs. Representatives of the EU Parliament and the member states reached an agreement to expand the Anti-Smuggling Center EMSC, as announced by the EU Commission. According to this, liaison officers from the EU judicial authority Eurojust and the EU border protection agency Frontex will also be part of it in the future.

Europol will receive 50 new employees and an additional financial support of 50 million euros for the fight against smugglers, according to the announcement. Of this, 20 million will be used for the improved processing of biometric data, such as fingerprints or facial images. The new commitments also stipulate that member states must share more information with Europol and other countries.

Europol currently has 1,400 employees. The EU agency based in The Hague, Netherlands, is supposed to help member states combat international and organized crime, cybercrime, and terrorism.

Agreement still needs to be formally confirmed

Europol plays a crucial role in supporting the national law enforcement and judicial authorities of the member states in dismantling the business models of smugglers and internationally operating criminal networks, the announcement stated. EU Migration Commissioner Magnus Brunner praised the agreement. “We must decide for ourselves who comes into the EU, not the smugglers,” said the Austrian politician.

The EU Commission proposed the regulation to strengthen Europol in November 2023. The agreement still needs to be formally confirmed by the European Parliament and the member states in the Council. (September 25)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the EU's significant commitment to strengthening Europol with increased funding, personnel, and powers to combat smuggling gangs. This action has broad societal impact by aiming to dismantle criminal networks that exploit vulnerable people, thereby protecting human rights and improving security across member states. The article provides clear details about the resources allocated and the expected cooperation improvements, indicating a meaningful policy development with tangible benefits.
articles.personality_title: EU boosts Europol with funds and staff to fight smuggling gangs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Smuggling gangs move people illegally across borders in Europe, causing problems for safety and law enforcement. Europol is the EU’s main agency helping countries work together to stop organized crime and smuggling.

**What happened** – The European Union agreed to give Europol 50 million euros and 50 extra staff members to fight smuggling gangs better. This includes new officers from Eurojust (the EU’s judicial agency) and Frontex (the EU’s border protection agency) joining the Anti-Smuggling Center. Member countries must now share more information with Europol to improve cooperation.

**Impact** – Europol will have better tools and more people to track and stop criminals who smuggle people illegally. For example, 20 million euros will be used to improve how Europol processes biometric data like fingerprints and facial images, helping identify suspects more quickly. This strengthens the EU’s ability to control who enters the region and protect vulnerable people from exploitation.

**What's next step** – The new plan still needs formal approval from the European Parliament and EU member states. Once approved, Europol can start using the new resources and powers to fight smuggling more effectively.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU is investing in Europol with more money, staff, and cooperation to better stop smuggling gangs and improve border security.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UE renforce Europol avec des fonds et du personnel pour lutter contre les réseaux de passeurs

**Ce qui s'est passé** – L'Union européenne a décidé de donner 50 millions d'euros et 50 agents supplémentaires à Europol pour mieux combattre les réseaux de passeurs. Des agents de Eurojust (l'agence judiciaire de l'UE) et de Frontex (l'agence de protection des frontières) rejoindront aussi le Centre Anti-Passeurs. Les pays membres doivent maintenant partager plus d'informations avec Europol pour améliorer la coopération.

**Impact** – Europol aura plus de moyens et de personnel pour suivre et arrêter les criminels qui font passer des personnes illégalement. Par exemple, 20 millions d'euros seront utilisés pour mieux traiter les données biométriques comme les empreintes digitales et les images faciales, ce qui aide à identifier plus rapidement les suspects. Cela renforce la capacité de l'UE à contrôler qui entre dans la région et à protéger les personnes vulnérables.

**Prochaine étape** – Ce plan doit encore être approuvé officiellement par le Parlement européen et les États membres de l'UE. Une fois approuvé, Europol pourra utiliser ces nouveaux moyens et pouvoirs pour mieux lutter contre les passeurs.

**En une phrase** – L'UE investit dans Europol avec plus d'argent, de personnel et de coopération pour mieux arrêter les réseaux de passeurs et renforcer la sécurité aux frontières.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE refuerza Europol con fondos y personal para combatir a las redes de traficantes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las redes de traficantes mueven personas ilegalmente a través de las fronteras en Europa, causando problemas de seguridad y justicia. Europol es la principal agencia de la UE que ayuda a los países a trabajar juntos para detener el crimen organizado y el tráfico ilegal.

**Qué pasó** – La Unión Europea acordó dar a Europol 50 millones de euros y 50 empleados adicionales para luchar mejor contra las redes de traficantes. También se sumarán oficiales de Eurojust (la agencia judicial de la UE) y Frontex (la agencia de protección fronteriza) al Centro Anti-Tráfico. Los países miembros ahora deben compartir más información con Europol para mejorar la cooperación.

**Impacto** – Europol tendrá mejores herramientas y más personas para rastrear y detener a los criminales que trafican personas ilegalmente. Por ejemplo, 20 millones de euros se usarán para mejorar el procesamiento de datos biométricos como huellas dactilares e imágenes faciales, ayudando a identificar sospechosos más rápido. Esto fortalece la capacidad de la UE para controlar quién entra y proteger a personas vulnerables.

**Próximo paso** – El plan aún necesita la aprobación formal del Parlamento Europeo y los estados miembros. Una vez aprobado, Europol podrá usar estos nuevos recursos y poderes para combatir mejor el tráfico.

**En una frase** – La UE está invirtiendo en Europol con más dinero, personal y cooperación para detener mejor a las redes de traficantes y mejorar la seguridad fronteriza.
